field_label:
Welcome to Exploring the Mind!

Exploring the Mind is a group of activities to research behavior and cognition. These activities will collect new types of data from you. They will measure things like:

  • the amount of time you are able to concentrate on a task without getting distracted
  • your process for making some decisions
  • how long it takes you to respond to a question or prompt
  • how often you respond correctly
  • your ability to recognize emotions

Please read the following information carefully. We will tell you more about these activities and how your participation can help researchers. At the end, we'll ask you if you want to take part in Exploring the Mind. You can choose 'yes' or 'no' and still participate in All of Us.

What Will You Ask Me to Do?

Each activity will ask you to do something different. They may be short exercises, quizzes, or puzzles. For example, one activity may ask you to look at pictures of faces and decide if they are happy or sad. Another may ask you to press a button when the screen shows a certain picture or to guess how many dots are on the screen. We may add new activities over time.

Before you do an activity, we will tell you about it. We will tell you about any accessibility limitations it may have. You can decide if you want to do that activity or not. You can choose to do some activities and not others.

How Am I Helping Research?

Understanding how our minds work is tricky. We still have a lot to learn. We are also learning the best ways to study the mind. If you take part in Exploring the Mind, you can help with both!

Your data from Exploring the Mind will be combined with data from other All of Us participants. The strength of All of Us is that our hundreds of thousands of participants reflect the many different people across the U.S. These people live in different circumstances and different environments and are at different life stages. Data from Exploring the Mind may help researchers find patterns about how our minds work across these differences. 

For example, data from Exploring the Mind can be used to look at things that influence our attention spans. Like time of day or average amount of sleep. They can be used to study when in life people get better at recognizing emotions. Or how different conditions may affect reaction speed or accuracy.

These data can also help researchers see how well the activities measure things about our behavior and cognition. They can use this information to improve the activities or develop new ones to get more helpful data for research.

What Will You Do With My Data?

We will add your data from Exploring the Mind activities to the other data you have shared with All of Us. We will add it to the All of Us databases. We will not include your name or other information that directly identifies you.
Researchers can use data from these activities to study many topics, including:

  • Mental health and mental health conditions
    • like depression or schizophrenia
  • Behavioral health and behavioral health conditions
    • like gambling or substance use disorder
  • Development and changes in thinking and reasoning over the lifespan

Researchers want to study these activities for all kinds of people with all kinds of brains. You do not need to have a mental, behavioral, or cognitive condition for your data to help research.

Are There Risks to Taking Part in Exploring the Mind?

The risks of taking part in Exploring the Mind include the risks of participating in All of Us. You can review those risks in the Consent to Join the All of Us Research Program in the Agreements area of your account.

There are also potential physical risks for some activities. Some activities will:

  • have rapidly changing or flashing images. These activities may affect people with photosensitive epilepsy or other conditions that may make them sensitive to flashing lights and images. We will tell you if there are rapidly changing or flashing images before the first time you do an activity.
  • ask you to respond to visual images. This can mean focusing on your screen for a period of time. This may cause eye discomfort for some people.
  • ask you to make fast or repeated movements. Like pressing a key, clicking with the mouse, or tapping your screen. These activities may cause discomfort for some people.

Before the first time you do each activity, we will tell you about what we will ask you to do. Please do not do any activity you think may cause you discomfort or harm.

Are There Emotional Risks to Taking Part in Exploring the Mind?

Some participants may be stressed or worried by participating in Exploring the Mind. For example:

  • Some activities will ask you to focus for a period of time. Others may ask you to recognize emotions on pictures of faces. If these activities are hard for you, they may frustrate you.
  • Most activities will let you see how you did when you finish them. They may tell you the number of questions you got right. Or how fast you responded. Your results could worry you. For example, you may not have done as well as you expected. Or how you do may change over time if you repeat the same activity.

Lots of things can influence how you do on these activities. Like, if you got enough sleep last night. Or if you're distracted. Your results aren't a reflection on your abilities. They aren't "good" or "bad."

It's important to remember that Exploring the Mind activities are for research. These activities do not provide medical information or a diagnosis. They will not tell you whether or not you have a mental, behavioral, or cognitive condition.

Time to Decide

The next screen is the informed consent form for Exploring the Mind. Review this document carefully. Then we will ask you if you want to take part in Exploring the Mind. If you say yes, we will ask you to sign the informed consent form. You get to choose. Whatever you decide, you will still be an All of Us participant.

If you still have questions, you can call, email, or chat with a representative from All of Us.

Would you like to take part in Exploring the Mind?

  • Yes
    • I know there will be different Exploring the Mind activities to do. I get to decide which activities I want to do.
    • I know that many Exploring the Mind activities will give me the option to see how I did after I finish them. Those results are not medical information or a diagnosis.
    • I know my data from Exploring the Mind will be added to the All of Us public and scientific databases. Researchers will use the data to make discoveries.
    • I know I can withdraw my consent to take part in Exploring the Mind at any time. There is no penalty. I will still be an All of Us participant.
  • No
    • I know I can change my mind later.

You have decided to participate in Exploring the Mind.


Please sign the informed consent form by typing your name in the box below.
If you prefer, you can select "Draw" instead. If you're using a computer, please use your mouse to sign. If you are using a mobile device, please use your finger to sign.

You have decided not to participate in Exploring the Mind.

You can change your mind whenever you want. If you change your mind, you can find this consent again in the Agreements section of your All of Us account.

One last question...

Did someone from All of Us help you with this consent process?
[radio button]

[note: If participant selects "yes," section below appears]
Please have the person who helped you type their name below.

Thank You for Completing This Consent.

Click "Get Started" to see your available activities.
